      • helloName

        public java.lang.String helloName(java.lang.String name)
        Given a string name, e.g. "Bob", return a greeting of the form "Hello Bob!". helloName("Bob") → "Hello Bob!" helloName("Alice") → "Hello Alice!" helloName("X") → "Hello X!"
        Parameters:
        name - string
        Returns:
        string, hello concatenates to the name param

      • makeOutWord

        public java.lang.String makeOutWord(java.lang.String out,
                                    java.lang.String word)
        Given an "out" string length 4, such as "<<>>", and a word, return a new string where the word is in the middle of the out string, e.g. "<>". Note: use str.substring(i, j) to extract the String starting at index i and going up to but not including index j. makeOutWord("<<>>", "Yay") → "<>" makeOutWord("<<>>", "WooHoo") → "<>" makeOutWord("[[]]", "word") → "[[word]]"
        Parameters:
        out - string, its length is 4
        word - string, it is probably a meaningful word
        Returns:
        string, where the word is in the middle of the out string

      • firstHalf

        public java.lang.String firstHalf(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string of even length, return the first half. So the string "WooHoo" yields "Woo". firstHalf("WooHoo") → "Woo" firstHalf("HelloThere") → "Hello" firstHalf("abcdef") → "abc"
        Parameters:
        str - stirng, its length is even
        Returns:
        string, it is the first half of the str param

      • nonStart

        public java.lang.String nonStart(java.lang.String a,
                                 java.lang.String b)
        Given 2 strings, return their concatenation, except omit the first char of each. The strings will be at least length 1. nonStart("Hello", "There") → "ellohere" nonStart("java", "code") → "avaode" nonStart("shotl", "java") → "hotlava"
        Parameters:
        a - string, its length at least 1
        b - string, its length at least 1
        Returns:
        string, its a and b concatenation , except omit the first char of each

      • theEnd

        public java.lang.String theEnd(java.lang.String str,
                               boolean front)
        Given a string, return a string length 1 from its front, unless front is false, in which case return a string length 1 from its back. The string will be non-empty. theEnd("Hello", true) → "H" theEnd("Hello", false) → "o" theEnd("oh", true) → "o"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length min 1
        front - false, its true if we are interested by the first letter of the str param
        Returns:
        string, its length is 1 from its front, unless front is false, in which case return a string length 1 from its back

      • endsLy

        public boolean endsLy(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return true if it ends in "ly". endsLy("oddly") → true endsLy("y") → false endsLy("oddy") → false
        Parameters:
        str - string
        Returns:
        boolean, it is true if the end of the str param is "ly"

      • middleThree

        public java.lang.String middleThree(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string of odd length, return the string length 3 from its middle, so "Candy" yields "and". The string length will be at least 3. middleThree("Candy") → "and" middleThree("and") → "and" middleThree("solving") → "lvi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length is odd ans at least 3
        Returns:
        string, its length 3 from its middle

      • lastChars

        public java.lang.String lastChars(java.lang.String a,
                                  java.lang.String b)
        Given 2 strings, a and b, return a new string made of the first char of a and the last char of b, so "yo" and "java" yields "ya". If either string is length 0, use '@' for its missing char. lastChars("last", "chars") → "ls" lastChars("yo", "java") → "ya" lastChars("hi", "") → "h@"
        Parameters:
        a - string
        b - string
        Returns:
        string, its first char of a and the last char of b, so "yo" and "java" yields "ya". If either string is length 0, use '@' for its missing char.

      • seeColor

        public java.lang.String seeColor(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, if the string begins with "red" or "blue" return that color string, otherwise return the empty string. seeColor("redxx") → "red" seeColor("xxred") → "" seeColor("blueTimes") → "blue"
        Parameters:
        str - string
        Returns:
        string, its "red" or "blue" if the str param starts any of those key word

      • extraFront

        public java.lang.String extraFront(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a new string made of 3 copies of the first 2 chars of the original string. The string may be any length. If there are fewer than 2 chars, use whatever is there. extraFront("Hello") → "HeHeHe" extraFront("ab") → "ababab" extraFront("H") → "HHH"
        Parameters:
        str - string
        Returns:
        string, its made of 3 copies of the first 2 chars of the original string. The string may be any length. If there are fewer than 2 chars, use whatever is there.

      • startWord

        public java.lang.String startWord(java.lang.String str,
                                  java.lang.String word)
        Given a string and a second "word" string, we'll say that the word matches the string if it appears at the front of the string, except its first char does not need to match exactly. On a match, return the front of the string, or otherwise return the empty string. So, so with the string "hippo" the word "hi" returns "hi" and "xip" returns "hip". The word will be at least length 1. startWord("hippo", "hi") → "hi" startWord("hippo", "xip") → "hip" startWord("hippo", "i") → "h"
        Parameters:
        str - string
        word - string
        Returns:
        string, its the word matches the string if it appears at the front of the string, except its first char does not need to match exactly. On a match, return the front of the string, or otherwise return the empty string.

      • makeAbba

        public java.lang.String makeAbba(java.lang.String a,
                                 java.lang.String b)
        Given two strings, a and b, return the result of putting them together in the order abba, e.g. "Hi" and "Bye" returns "HiByeByeHi". makeAbba("Hi", "Bye") → "HiByeByeHi" makeAbba("Yo", "Alice") → "YoAliceAliceYo" makeAbba("What", "Up") → "WhatUpUpWhat"
        Parameters:
        a - string
        b - string
        Returns:
        string, it concats a to b to b to a

      • extraEnd

        public java.lang.String extraEnd(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a new string made of 3 copies of the last 2 chars of the original string. The string length will be at least 2. extraEnd("Hello") → "lololo" extraEnd("ab") → "ababab" extraEnd("Hi") → "HiHiHi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length at least 2
        Returns:
        string, its mafe of 3 copies of str param last 2 chars

      • withoutEnd

        public java.lang.String withoutEnd(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a version without the first and last char, so "Hello" yields "ell". The string length will be at least 2. withoutEnd("Hello") → "ell" withoutEnd("java") → "av" withoutEnd("coding") → "odin"
        Parameters:
        str - string, ist length at least 2
        Returns:
        string, str param without the first and last chars

      • left2

        public java.lang.String left2(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a "rotated left 2" version where the first 2 chars are moved to the end. The string length will be at least 2. left2("Hello") → "lloHe" left2("java") → "vaja" left2("Hi") → "Hi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length min 2
        Returns:
        string, its version of rotated left 2 indexes of str param

      • withouEnd2

        public java.lang.String withouEnd2(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a version without both the first and last char of the string. The string may be any length, including 0. withouEnd2("Hello") → "ell" withouEnd2("abc") → "b" withouEnd2("ab") → ""
        Parameters:
        str - string, could be any length
        Returns:
        string, its version without both the first and last char of the string

      • nTwice

        public java.lang.String nTwice(java.lang.String str,
                               int n)
        Given a string and an int n, return a string made of the first and last n chars from the string. The string length will be at least n. nTwice("Hello", 2) → "Helo" nTwice("Chocolate", 3) → "Choate" nTwice("Chocolate", 1) → "Ce"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length az least n
        n - int, non-negative number
        Returns:
        string, its made of the first and last n chars from the string

      • hasBad

        public boolean hasBad(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return true if "bad" appears starting at index 0 or 1 in the string, such as with "badxxx" or "xbadxx" but not "xxbadxx". The string may be any length, including 0. Note: use .equals() to compare 2 strings. hasBad("badxx") → true hasBad("xbadxx") → true hasBad("xxbadxx") → false
        Parameters:
        str - string
        Returns:
        boolean, it is true if "bad" appears starting at index 0 or 1 in the srt param

      • conCat

        public java.lang.String conCat(java.lang.String a,
                               java.lang.String b)
        Given two strings, append them together (known as "concatenation") and return the result. However, if the concatenation creates a double-char, then omit one of the chars, so "abc" and "cat" yields "abcat". conCat("abc", "cat") → "abcat" conCat("dog", "cat") → "dogcat" conCat("abc", "") → "abc"
        Parameters:
        a - string
        b - string
        Returns:
        string, it appends a and b params together. However, if the concatenation creates a double-char, then omit one of the chars.

      • frontAgain

        public boolean frontAgain(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return true if the first 2 chars in the string also appear at the end of the string, such as with "edited". frontAgain("edited") → true frontAgain("edit") → false frontAgain("ed") → true
        Parameters:
        str - string
        Returns:
        boolean, its true if the first 2 chars in the string also appear at the end of the string

      • without2

        public java.lang.String without2(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, if a length 2 substring appears at both its beginning and end, return a string without the substring at the beginning, so "HelloHe" yields "lloHe". The substring may overlap with itself, so "Hi" yields "". Otherwise, return the original string unchanged. without2("HelloHe") → "lloHe" without2("HelloHi") → "HelloHi" without2("Hi") → ""
        Parameters:
        str - string, can be any length
        Returns:
        string, its if length 2 substring appears at both its beginning and end, return a string without the substring at the beginning. Otherwise, return the original string unchanged.

      • withoutX

        public java.lang.String withoutX(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, if the first or last chars are 'x', return the string without those 'x' chars, and otherwise return the string unchanged. withoutX("xHix") → "Hi" withoutX("xHi") → "Hi" withoutX("Hxix") → "Hxi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, can has any length
        Returns:
        string, its if the first or last chars are 'x', return the string without those 'x' chars, and otherwise return the string unchanged

      • makeTags

        public java.lang.String makeTags(java.lang.String tag,
                                 java.lang.String word)
        The web is built with HTML strings like "Yay" which draws Yay as italic text. In this example, the "i" tag makes and which surround the word "Yay". Given tag and word strings, create the HTML string with tags around the word, e.g. "Yay". makeTags("i", "Yay") → "Yay" makeTags("i", "Hello") → "Hello" makeTags("cite", "Yay") → "Yay"
        Parameters:
        tag - string, its an html tag
        word - string, it can have any length
        Returns:
        string, it concats tag to word to escape tag as the html temp allows

      • firstTwo

        public java.lang.String firstTwo(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return the string made of its first two chars, so the String "Hello" yields "He". If the string is shorter than length 2, return whatever there is, so "X" yields "X", and the empty string "" yields the empty string "". Note that str.length() returns the length of a string. firstTwo("Hello") → "He" firstTwo("abcdefg") → "ab" firstTwo("ab") → "ab"
        Parameters:
        str - string, can be any length
        Returns:
        string, its made of its first two chars or if the string is shorter than length 2, return whatever there is

      • comboString

        public java.lang.String comboString(java.lang.String a,
                                    java.lang.String b)
        Given 2 strings, a and b, return a string of the form short+long+short, with the shorter string on the outside and the longer string on the inside. The strings will not be the same length, but they may be empty (length 0). comboString("Hello", "hi") → "hiHellohi" comboString("hi", "Hello") → "hiHellohi" comboString("aaa", "b") → "baaab"
        Parameters:
        a - string, can be any length
        b - string, can be any length
        Returns:
        string, concats the shortest param to longest param to shortest param

      • right2

        public java.lang.String right2(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a "rotated right 2" version where the last 2 chars are moved to the start. The string length will be at least 2. right2("Hello") → "loHel" right2("java") → "vaja" right2("Hi") → "Hi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length min 2
        Returns:
        string, str param is rotated by right 2

      • middleTwo

        public java.lang.String middleTwo(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string of even length, return a string made of the middle two chars, so the string "string" yields "ri". The string length will be at least 2. middleTwo("string") → "ri" middleTwo("code") → "od" middleTwo("Practice") → "ct"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length is even and ate least 2
        Returns:
        string, its made of the middle two chars

      • twoChar

        public java.lang.String twoChar(java.lang.String str,
                                int index)
        Given a string and an index, return a string length 2 starting at the given index. If the index is too big or too small to define a string length 2, use the first 2 chars. The string length will be at least 2. twoChar("java", 0) → "ja" twoChar("java", 2) → "va" twoChar("java", 3) → "ja"
        Parameters:
        str - string, its length min 2
        index - int, can be any int number
        Returns:
        string, its length 2 starting at the given index. If the index is too big or too small to define a string length 2, use the first 2 chars. The string length will be at least 2.

      • atFirst

        public java.lang.String atFirst(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a string length 2 made of its first 2 chars. If the string length is less than 2, use '@' for the missing chars. atFirst("hello") → "he" atFirst("hi") → "hi" atFirst("h") → "h@"
        Parameters:
        str - string, can be any length
        Returns:
        string, its length 2 made of its first 2 chars. If the string length is less than 2, use '@' for the missing chars.

      • lastTwo

        public java.lang.String lastTwo(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string of any length, return a new string where the last 2 chars, if present, are swapped, so "coding" yields "codign". lastTwo("coding") → "codign" lastTwo("cat") → "cta" lastTwo("ab") → "ba"
        Parameters:
        str - string, can be any length
        Returns:
        string, its where the last 2 chars, if present, are swapped

      • minCat

        public java.lang.String minCat(java.lang.String a,
                               java.lang.String b)
        Given two strings, append them together (known as "concatenation") and return the result. However, if the strings are different lengths, omit chars from the longer string so it is the same length as the shorter string. So "Hello" and "Hi" yield "loHi". The strings may be any length. minCat("Hello", "Hi") → "loHi" minCat("Hello", "java") → "ellojava" minCat("java", "Hello") → "javaello"
        Parameters:
        a - string ,may be any length
        b - string ,may be any length
        Returns:
        string, its append a and b param together. However, if the strings are different lengths, omit chars from the longer string so it is the same length as the shorter string.

      • deFront

        public java.lang.String deFront(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, return a version without the first 2 chars. Except keep the first char if it is 'a' and keep the second char if it is 'b'. The string may be any length. Harder than it looks. deFront("Hello") → "llo" deFront("java") → "va" deFront("away") → "aay"
        Parameters:
        str - string, may be any length
        Returns:
        string, its a version without the first 2 chars. Except keep the first char if it is 'a' and keep the second char if it is 'b'.

      • withoutX2

        public java.lang.String withoutX2(java.lang.String str)
        Given a string, if one or both of the first 2 chars is 'x', return the string without those 'x' chars, and otherwise return the string unchanged. This is a little harder than it looks. withoutX2("xHi") → "Hi" withoutX2("Hxi") → "Hi" withoutX2("Hi") → "Hi"
        Parameters:
        str - string, may be any length
        Returns:
        string, its without those 'x' chars, and otherwise return the string unchanged
